content: Test 4 and Validator 4 violate the statement that "the quantity of fake gold must be strictly less than half of the total (fake + real) gold sold," as it's not true that 0 < 0.

Validator 1 had a trailing newline, which differed from the rest of the tests and validators. This was an issue because solutions that do not print a newline would pass all of the tests, but fail that single validator. I updated your contribution to remove the extraneous newline.

It should be made clear, that "total gold" includes fake gold, since fake gold is not gold, even if Edward tells his costumers so.
Ambiguities like that make bug hunting more difficult.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a very nice idea for a quick coding challenge and just complicated enough to spice things up

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice idea for a quick clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good idea ! Easy to understand, I really like this clash.
Solved in 6 min
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Maybe mention that the amount of fake coins has to be *strictly* less than half? When reading the statement I assumed that if half of the gold was fake, that would still be fine.

well when you talked about alchemy, maybe you should use a silver also to make fake gold, its seems like silver has no utility in your problem, you can say you can make fake gold with 1 coin of silver and 2 coins of lead
Interesting code. Learned alot of new things

The default print statement in the IDE is still print("Edward made 123 coins today")
whereas it is supposed to say "can make" instead of "made" according to the problem statement.
I would suggest leaving the text out altogether, instead only outputting the number of coins.

I like the idea but you should randomize the order of entry of materials, that would make it a little harder.

And maybe vary the prices, like an entry that gives the value of one of the materials something like that. But do it the way you feel.

By the way, mention that the total gold sold include fake gold.

P.S : My solution :

a = input().split()
Ag = int(a[1])
Pb = int(a[3])
Au = int(a[5])
Fake_Au = min(Pb , Au - 1) if Au>0 else 0
Pb = Pb - Fake_Au
print(f"Edward can make {Ag * 10 + Pb + Au * 100 + Fake_Au * 100} coins today")

Goal section
* Please change "1" to "1 coin", "10" to "10 coins" and "100" to "100 coins", as the statement is incomplete without mentioning the unit.

Input section
* Please mention that the quantities are integers.

* Please mention that the names and the quantities are space-separated.

* Please change "i.e." to "e.g.".

Output section
* Suggest to remove the quotation marks around "value" (first line).

* Please format the second line as follows:
{{Edward made}} [[value]] {{coins today}}

Thanks.
Thank you for your feedback :)

I like the idea of randomizing the order of entry.

Please try your solution in the IDE, it doesn't seem to work when Au = 0

I will change the answer to "can make" to avoid the confusion in the output format

Thank you :)

I didn't noticed this part was still unfixed
Wouldn't it be a bit difficult for beginners?

Thank you for the feedback :)

I changed it to make it clearer and highlight the part in bold

Thanks for your feedback

I hope it's easier to understand now

I didn't find any mistake.

Could you share your code to try to find the problem?

This ruby code passed 100% of the tests, but only 75% of the validators:

eval"A,P,G="+gets.scan(/\d+/)*?,
$><<"Edward can make #{A*10+(P-f=[P,[0,G-1].max].min)+(f+G)*100} coins today"

The reason this passed only 75% of the validators is because $><< does not print with a newline in ruby. 

Prior to my change, validator 1 expected the following output (notice that it has a newline):
"Edward can make 1373 coins today
"

The expected output should look like this, without a newline:
"Edward can make 1373 coins today"

After I removed the trailing newline from Validator 1's expected output, the ruby code now passes 100% of the validators. 

I already updated the contribution, so the issue is fixed.
Thank you :)

a = input().split()
Ag = int(a[1])
Pb = int(a[3])
Au = int(a[5])
Fake_Au = min(Pb , Au - 1) if Au>0 else 0
Pb = Pb - Fake_Au
print(f"Edward can make {Ag * 10 + Pb + Au * 100 + Fake_Au * 100} coins today")
For shortest mode, I think it's possible to do it in 140 characters using python
let me try

135 characters :

a=input().split()
P=int(a[3])
A=int(a[5])
F=min(P,A-1) if A>0 else 0
P-=F
print(f"Edward can make {int(a[1])*10+P+A*100+F*100} coins today")

Perhaps its possible to do less with another method
Yeah, it's still possible to reduce it a little. But I think it's not good to write it, so people can try to find by themselves
